results.summary: The founder of The Big Issue magazine says the killing of two homeless vendors in Birmingham "almost destroyed" the organisation's belief in itself.
results.body: <body xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/16ef6dd5-44cf-3a4e-baff-1adecdc4b9b8"><image id="70475618"/><paragraph role="introduction">The killings of two sellers of The Big Issue "almost destroyed" the organisation's "belief in ourselves", its founder has said.</paragraph><paragraph>Wayne Busst, 32, and Ian Watson-Gladwish, 31, both homeless men from Birmingham, were stabbed in Union Street in the city centre on 11 January. </paragraph><paragraph>John Ward, 23, of no fixed address, denied murder but admitted manslaughter on the grounds of diminished responsibility. He was given a minimum tariff of 12 years.</paragraph><paragraph>The Big Issue founder John Bird said following the deaths, there were a number of people at the magazine organisation who said it "can't leave people in this situation".</paragraph><paragraph>He added: "I found it very difficult because being the person who put the whole thing together, I thought... maybe I shouldn't have bothered.</paragraph><paragraph>"When we thought about it, obviously when you've got 22 years [of The Big Issue] and you look at the amount of people who have been injured and hurt and the people who have been killed, it's a very small amount for that amount of time.</paragraph><paragraph>"But every time somebody gets attacked or murdered, you do stop and think. It wouldn't be human not to stop and think 'isn't there another way to do it?'" </paragraph><crosshead>'Incredibly dangerous'</crosshead><paragraph>The magazine is sold on the streets by homeless people, who themselves have to initially buy the copies for 50% of the cover price. The intention is that the vendors earn money but also take charge of their finances, develop coping skills and boost their self-esteem.</paragraph><paragraph>But Mr Bird said the charity was now "building other ways" of working with homeless people by "turning them into content providers" for The Big Issue's digital magazine.</paragraph><paragraph>"So some people could come to us and say 'we want to do things but we don't want to sell on the streets'," he said.</paragraph><paragraph>"The streets are incredibly dangerous. They always have been. They always will be. But the way in which The Big Issue has rallied I think is exemplary. </paragraph><image id="65251617"/><paragraph>"The public were enormously supportive of our staff and our vendors, so we kind of weathered it, but it raises very big issues that I've been working on for a few years because I'm an ex-runaway and rough sleeper and I knew how vulnerable it was [on the streets]."</paragraph><paragraph>Mr Bird said staff took what happened "very, very badly" and the organisation "had to do a lot of hand holding because they knew the vendors very well".</paragraph><paragraph>The Big Issue runs "a very tight" street support service, he added, but it was "very difficult to protect people from the public".</paragraph><paragraph>The magazine founder said: "I don't know what else we could do.</paragraph><paragraph>"We will always be vulnerable to some random person who may have had some great problem in their lives which has led them to become psychotic."</paragraph><paragraph>Mr Bird said he used to see people who were mentally ill on the streets and who "are harming themselves and could possibly harm others".</paragraph><paragraph>He said: "If I had my way, I'd pick all these people up and take them to a place of safety. I wouldn't put them back in the old asylums. </paragraph><paragraph>"I would put them in a place of safety where they don't harm other people and they don't harm themselves."</paragraph></body>
